bibl.title: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Albert E. Truby, December 10, 1941

div1.p: Ireland discusses Lazear's laboratory notebook, which is at the New York Academy of Medicine library. He is convinced that Hench will retrieve valuable information from it.

div1.head: Letter from Merritte W. Ireland to Albert E. Truby, December 10, 1941
div1.opener:
1870 Wyoming Avenue,
Washington, D.C.,
December 10, 1941
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
General A. E. Truby, U.S.A., Ret.,
145 Laurel Street,
San Francisco, Calif.
My dear Truby:
div1.p:
I have your very interesting letter of November 30th and
should have answered it two or three days ago but I have been busy
and did not have an opportunity until yesterday morning to get
over and talk to Kean.

You had better believe the little baby was at the wedding
and I held her in my arms. She is a little dear. Ben and Barbara
were there. The wedding was beautiful in every respect and I miss
my guess if Lilla did not get a fine up-standing man. He looks the
part.

I was very much interested in what you said about the Lazear
book in the New York Academy of Medicine library. It is just what you
said--the laboratory notebook about mosquitoes which Neate gave Reed.
When Hench gets down there, I have no doubt he will dig a lot of very
valuable information out of it. He is some boy to dig up information.

Now about your own manuscript: I never knew and neither did
Kean know that the New York Academy of Medicine published books of
any size. Of course, their circulation could be made just as big as
they wanted to make it. Kean and I agree that, if we were in your
place, we would not send the manuscript on to Mahlon Ashford but
would write to him and tell him what you are doing and about the size
of the book and ask him if his proposition of 1938 is still good in
regard to a manuscript of the size of the one you have prepared. In
the meantime, I am going to talk to the Surgeon General's Office and
find out how wide a distribution they would make of the Medical Bulle-
tin if you use that as a method of publication. I think they could make
the distribution just as wide as they wanted to. I will let you know
about that just as soon as I can find out. I don't see any reason why
there should be a great hurry in getting the book published although
as Straub used to say “the sooner, the quicker”.

Of course, everything is in a hurry around here now and I pre-
sume you are wearing a tin hat out in San Francisco for fear you will
be hit by something from the air if you go out of the house.

With all sorts of good wishes for you and Mrs. Truby and with
the Season's Greetings,
div1.closer:
Faithfully yours, Ireland
the Bulletin is not limited to the
Action Officers - about 11,000
